revisions.rev:
The following '''List of Presidents of Colombia''' is a list in [[chronological order]] of the persons who have occupied the [[President of Colombia|Office of the President of Colombia]] or similar office during its [[History of Colombia|history]] since achieving Independence in 1810. Because of historical events and constitutional restrictions, the Chief Executive Officers of [[Colombia]] have not always been called [[President]]s, but have held the office under various titles. ==Foolish Fatherland (During the Reign of Fernando VII)== The [[Foolish Fatherland]] is a historical period where the colonies of the [[Viceroyalty of the New Granada]] first experimented with [[self-rule]]. After the incarceration of Emperor [[Ferdinand VII of Spain]] by [[Napoleon Bonaparte]], several cities across the empire cut ties with the shadow government of Napoleon's brother, [[Joseph Bonaparte|Joseph I]], who had crowned himself King of Spain. As the news of this unrest reached the New World various cities declared independence from Spain. In the New Granada, given the fraction of its territory, various provinces declared themselves independent and set up their own governments headed by [[Criollo people|Criollos]]. The office of President was then first implemented in the country by regional leaders. ===Regional Presidents=== ====State of Cundinamarca (1810â1814) (During the Reign of Fernando VII)==== On January 29, 1810 the [[Supreme Central and Governing Junta of the Kingdom]] in [[CÃ¡diz]] dissolved under the pressure of French troops during the [[Siege of CÃ¡diz]], thus ending the last bastillion of the Spanish Resistance in mainland Spain. When news of this event reached the New World local political leaders sought to take advantage of the situation and set up [[junta (Peninsular War)|juntas]] headed by [[Criollo people|Criollos]]. In BogotÃ¡, the capital of the Viceroyalty of the New Granada news of this event reached on July 20, 1810 and the events that followed led to the formation of the Open Cabildo of BogotÃ¡. At first the Cabildo sought to gain legitimacy by including the Viceroy in their leadership, but he refused to do so and was replaced by the Vice President of the Cabildo, the [[Mayor of BogotÃ¡]], [[JosÃ© Miguel Pey de Andrade]] making him the first Criollo to hold executive and legislative power over the territory that is now Colombia. As independence spread over the empire, the Cabildo was replaced by the Government of the Free and Independent State of Cundinamarca, with BogotÃ¡ as its capital and [[Jorge Tadeo Lozano]] as its President, or as his title indicated "President of Cundinamarca and Vicegerent of the King's Person." The independent Republic of Cundinamarca lasted until 1812, when this one was incorporated into the United Provinces of the New Granada. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%; line-height:normal" |- style="text-align:center; background:#e6e9ff;" ! colspan=6 | [[File:Escudo de BogotÃ¡.svg|30px]] â¢ [[Open Cabildo]] of [[BogotÃ¡]] â¢ [[File:Escudo de BogotÃ¡.svg|30px]] |- style="text-align:center; background:#e6e9ff;" !width=11%|Picture!!width=20%|Name!!width=15%|Took office!!width=15%|Left office!!Form of Ascension!!Reason for stepping down |- align=center |[[File:Antonio Jose Amar y Borb n.JPG|80px]]||'''[[Antonio JosÃ© Amar y BorbÃ³n|Antonio JosÃ©
Amar y BorbÃ³n]]'''||''did not take office''||||President-elect of Cabildo, but refuses to accept office.||Permanently replaced. |- align=center |[[File:JosÃ© Miguel Pey.jpg|80px]]||'''[[JosÃ© Miguel Pey de Andrade|JosÃ© Miguel
Pey de Andrade]]'''||July 20, 1810||April 1, 1811||Vice President acting as President in his absence. Eventually elected nominal President.||Office subjugated to that of Cundinamarca. |- style="text-align:center; background:#e6e9ff;" ! colspan=8 | [[File:Escudo de Cundinamarca.svg|30px]] â¢ Independent State of [[Free and Independent State of Cundinamarca|Cundinamarca]] â¢ [[File:Escudo de Cundinamarca.svg|30px]] |- style="text-align:center; background:#e6e9ff;" !width=11%|Picture!!width=20%|Name!!width=15%|Took office!!width=15%|Left office!!Form of Ascension!!Reason for stepping down |- align=center |[[File:Lozajorg.jpg|80px]]||'''[[Jorge Tadeo Lozano|Jorge

Office subjugated to that of the United Provinces of New Granada.. |} ===State of Cartagena de Indias (1810â1812) (During the Reign of Fernando VII)=== {{Main|List of Governors of the Province of Cartagena#Peninsular War, Revolution and Independence (1810-1820)}} When news of the declaration of independence of the Cabildo of BogotÃ¡ reached the port city of [[Cartagena de Indias]], local leaders moved to form their own Supreme Junta on August 13, 1810, and subsequently on November 11, 1811 declared absolute independence from Spain and from the Viceroyalty of New Granada becoming its own nation, initially under the leadership of [[JosÃ© Ignacio de Cavero y CÃ¡rdenas]] as President of the Junta, and afterwards under a Governor President until the incorporation of Cartagena into the United Provinces of New Granada. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%; line-height:normal" |- style="text-align:center; background:#e6e9ff;" ! colspan=6 | [[File:Antiguo escudo de Cartagena de Indias.svg|30px]] â¢ [[Junta (Peninsular War)|Supreme Junta]] of [[Cartagena de Indias]] â¢ [[File:Escudo de Cartagena de Indias.svg|30px]] |- style="text-align:center; background:#e6e9ff;" !width=11%|Picture!!width=20%|Name!!width=15%|Took office!!width=15%|Left office!!Form of Ascension!!Reason for stepping down |- align=center |[[File:Colpres proyecto.png|80px]]||'''[[JosÃ© Ignacio de Cavero y CÃ¡rdenas|JosÃ© Ignacio
Cavero y CÃ¡rdenas]]'''||November 11, 1811||January 21, 1812||President of the Supreme Junta of Government||Office subjugated to the new State. |- align=center |[[File:Colpres proyecto.png|80px]]||'''[[JosÃ© MarÃ­a del Real e Hidalgo|JosÃ© MarÃ­a
del Real e Hidalgo]]'''||January 21, 1812||April 1, 1812||Elected Governor President of the State.||Office replaced. |- align=center |[[File:Fi 49 RodrÃ­guez Torices, Manuel.jpg|80px]]||'''[[Manuel RodrÃ­guez Torices|Manuel
RodrÃ­guez Torices]]'''||April 26, 1815||November 15, 1815||Elected President-Dictator by Convention of Cartagena.||Office subjugated to that of the United Provinces of New Granada. |} ====Republic of Antioquia (1810â1815) (During the Reign of Fernando VII)==== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%; line-height:normal" |- style="text-align:center; background:#e6e9ff;" ! colspan=6 | [[File:Sello Republica de Antioquia.svg|30px]] â¢ [[Antioquia|Republic of Antioquia]] â¢ [[File:Escudo de Antioquia.svg|20px]] |- style="text-align:center; background:#e6e9ff;" !width=11%|Picture!!width=20%|Name!!width=15%|Took office!!width=15%|Left office!!Form of Ascension!!Reason for stepping down |} ====Republic of Tunja (1812) (During the Reign of Fernando VII)==== The Province of [[Tunja]] had originally refuted the actions of BogotÃ¡ in declaring independence from Spain, but as cities within its own province started to clamour for independence by joining Cundinamarca who had already attained theirs, Tunja was forced to act quickly. On November 26, 1811 Tunja signed the Act of Confederation joining the United Provinces of New Granada, and on December 9, 1811 declared its formal independence from Spain. The tensions between Cundinamarca and the United Provinces however forced Tunja to enter into a treaty with Cundinamarca; the ''Santa Rosa Pact'' separated Tunja from the Federalist government of the United Provinces and put it in track to eventually join the Centralist government of Cundinamarca. The Republic of Tunja was now standing in its own two feet under the administration of President-Governor [[Juan Nepomuceno NiÃ±o]], this lasted until Cundinamarca was finally defeated and Tunja rejoined the United Provinces. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%; line-height:normal" |- style="text-align:center; background:#e6e9ff;" ! colspan=6 | [[File:Escudo de Tunja.svg|30px]] â¢ [[Tunja|Republic of Tunja]] â¢ [[File:Escudo de Tunja.svg|30px]] |- style="text-align:center; background:#e6e9ff;" !width=11%|Picture!!width=20%|Name!!width=15%|Took office!!width=15%|Left office!!Form of Ascension!!Reason for stepping down |- align=center |[[File:Colpres proyecto.png|80px]]||'''[[Juan Nepomuceno NiÃ±o|Juan Nepomuceno
NiÃ±o y Muelle]]'''||July 3, 1812||October 4, 1812||Elected President-Governor of Tunja by its Junta.||Office subjugated to that of the United Provinces of New Granada. |} ===United Provinces of New Granada (1812â1816) (During the Reign of Fernando VII)=== {{Main|United Provinces of New Granada}} The United Provinces of New Granada was formed on November 26, 1811 as a [[Confederation]] of the independent provinces of Tunja, [[Pamplona, Colombia|Pamplona]], [[Antioquia]], [[Cartagena, Colombia|Cartagena]] and [[Neiva, Huila|Neiva]]. The office of the President was at first non-existent, the provinces did not want to entrust power to one person in order to avoid favoritism. During its first formal assembly, the Federal Congress elected as its first President [[Camilo Torres Tenorio]] and entrusted him with executive power while a Triumvirate was set up. The [[Triumvirate]], was an experimental form of executive power in which three individuals would parallel and equally share executive power, giving more representation to various provinces at once; the system however, was flawed and ultimately proved difficult to maintain in light of the invasion by [[Pablo Morillo]] and its leaders were persecuted, forced to pass along power in a [[relay race]] for time and survival until all of its leaders were finally killed, or captured. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%; line-height:normal" |- style="text-align:center; background:#e6e9ff;" ! colspan=8 | [[File:Flag of New Granada (1814-1816).svg|30px]] â¢ [[United Provinces of New Granada]] â¢ [[File:Escudo de las Provincias Unidas de Nueva Granada.svg|30px]] |- style="text-align:center; background:#e6e9ff;" !width=11%|Picture!!width=19%|Name!!width=15%|Took office!!width=15%|Left office!!Form of Ascension!!Reason for stepping down |- align=center |[[File:Camilotorres.jpg|80px]]||'''[[Camilo Torres Tenorio|Camilo
Torres Tenorio]]'''||October 4, 1812||October 5, 1814||President of the Congress, entrusted with the Federal Executive Power.||Replaced by Triumvirate. |- align=center |[[File:Fi 51 Castillo y Rada, JosÃ© MarÃ­a.jpg|80px]]||'''[[JosÃ© MarÃ­a del Castillo Rada|JosÃ© MarÃ­a
del Castillo Rada]]'''||October 5, 1814||November 28, 1814||Interim Triumvir.||Term ends. |- align=center |[[File:Joaquin Camacho.jpg|80px]]||'''[[JoaquÃ­n Camacho|JoaquÃ­n
Camacho Lago]]'''||October 5, 1814||January 25, 1815||Interim Triumvir.||Term ends. |- align=center |[[File:Fernjose.jpg|80px]]||'''[[JosÃ© FernÃ¡ndez Madrid|JosÃ©

GarcÃ­a Rovira]]'''||November 28, 1814||July 24, 1815||Nominal Triumvir.||Term ends. |- align=center |[[File:JosÃ© Miguel Pey.jpg|80px]]||'''[[JosÃ© Miguel Pey de Andrade|JosÃ© Miguel

Villavicencio y VerÃ¡stegui]]'''||August 17, 1815||November 15, 1815||Alternate Triumvir, replaced GarcÃ­a.||Term ends. |- align=center |[[File:Jose Manuel Restrepo Velez.jpg|80px]]||'''[[JosÃ© Manuel Restrepo|JosÃ© Manuel

FernÃ¡ndez Madrid]]'''||March 14, 1816||June 22, 1816||Appointed by Congress.||Escaped the capital and resigned due to Spanish persecution. |- align=center |[[File:Mejilibo.jpg|80px]]||'''[[Liborio MejÃ­a GutiÃ©rrez|Liborio
MejÃ­a GutiÃ©rrez]]'''||June 22, 1816||June 30, 1816||Vice President appointed by Congress acting as President in his absence.||President takes office. |- align=center |[[File:GarcÃ­a Rovira.jpg|80px]]||'''[[Custodio GarcÃ­a Rovira|Custodio
GarcÃ­a Rovira]]'''||June 30, 1816||July 10, 1816||Appointed President-Dictator by Congress.||Captured by the Spanish Army. |- align=center |[[File:Fi 53 Serrano, Fernando.jpg|80px]]||'''[[Fernando Serrano Uribe|Fernando
Serrano Uribe]]'''||July 16, 1816||September 16, 1816||Elected by an assembly of army units.||Captured by the Spanish Army. |} ==Reign of Terror (1816â1819)== {{Main|List of Viceroys of New Granada}} The culmination of the [[Spanish reconquest of New Granada]] was the reinstitution of the Vice-royalty and the return of Spanish rule. The office of President was abolished in the colony and those fighting for independence were either captured, killed, forced underground or forced into exile; this period is known as the ''Reign of Terror'', a period when the Spanish colonial rulers sought to set an example of all of those who have defied the crown by setting [[show trial]]s and sentencing many of the Precursors of independence to death in public displays. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%; line-height:normal" |- style="text-align:center; background:#e6e9ff;" ! colspan=6 | [[File:Flag of Spain (1785-1873 and 1875-1931).svg|30px]] â¢ [[Spanish reconquest of New Granada|Spanish Reconquista of New Granada]] â¢ [[File:Escudo de BogotÃ¡.svg|30px]] |} ==Republic of Colombia (1819â1831)== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%; line-height:normal" |- style="text-align:center; background:#e6e9ff;" ! colspan=8 | [[File:Bandera de la Gran Colombia 1819.svg|30px]] â¢ 1st [[Gran Colombia|Republic of Colombia]] â¢ [[File:Coat of arms of Gran Colombia (1819).svg|30px]] |- style="text-align:center; background:#e6e9ff;" !Picture!! style="width:130px;"|Name!! style="width:115px;"|Took office!! style="width:115px;"|Left office!!Form of Ascension!!Reason for stepping down |- align=center |[[File:SimÃ³n BolÃ­var 2.jpg|80px]]||'''[[SimÃ³n BolÃ­var|SimÃ³n
BolÃ­var Palacios]]'''||February 15, 1819||December 13, 1821||Elected by the [[Congress of Angostura]] in 1819. Santander y OmaÃ±a]]'''||December 13, 1821||November 14, 1826||Vice President, in charge of the executive power.||President returns. |- align=center |[[File:SimÃ³n BolÃ­var 2.jpg|80px]]||'''[[SimÃ³n BolÃ­var|SimÃ³n
